reviewText:
Key finding simulator. If you like doing nothing but looking for keys, this game is for you.  This game actually had some promise in the early stages.  The demo they released for the Kickstarter campaigns was actually not bad.  In fact, you played the beginning of the game without having to find any keys at all.  Why they decided to turn it into an ugly version of Pineview Drive I'll never know.  Looking for keys is not acceptable gameplay in my book.

In other news, this dev is toxic. Here's a rundown of their behavior:

1) They ban you for negative comments on their forums.  I got a permanent ban for pointing out that they had run 5 kickstarters for this game (2 successful).  They said it was a false accusation, but you can go to Kickstarter and see it for yourself (although they've changed the names around to make it harder to find).

2) They delete all negative comments on their Greenlight submissions.

3) They have a UnitZ asset pack in the Steam store.

reviewText:
I'll start off by saying this review is in no way influenced by the developers decision to not give steam keys to people who purchased the game in the groupees bundle...  Even though I went ahead and purchased the game, I still think the Developer has an obligation to people who already purchased the game to provide them with a key.... enough on that subject...

Where to start with One Final Breath, it looks in the trailers to be your prototypical First person horror experience..  The graphics are decent, not the most impressive but very passable.  The game play is your typical search the random dark place to answer some burning questions or solve some type of question.  This game isn't an exception as you are tasked with finding your daughter who has run away from home.

As you explore the abandoned St. Mary's school, you'll find scattered notes left behind to help you piece together the history and get some back story on the building.

The first part in what will eventually be a five part episodic game.  So my review could change as future episodes are released (if they are released)  Ultimately it still remains to be seen what the developer has to offer in the future with this game.

Some negitives I've taken from the game... it's too dark with no options available to brighten it up.  Dubious audio quality with no option to turn on Subtitles.  Seems to be a key hunting simulator thus far.  In fact when it comes to in game options non exist..  Prior to starting up the game you can alter a few settings but for a game like this you should really be able to have on the fly changes.  The audio is either missing or needs to be made more clear/ or turned up as my character made numerous references to sounds which I didn't hear from my speakers or headphones..  The spelling, well this one isn't a deal breaker but still.... what is a WONG key?

Also about 40 minutes into my playthrough the screen became transparent, then slowly went dark, the mouse cursor was stuck in the middle of the screen and I couldn't control it, attempts to move the mouse were meet with the cursor thrashing back and force in a one inch hidden square.  I was unable to do anyting at all, I eventually had to ctl, alt, del out of the game then manually close it out..  It wound up costing me the 39 minutes I had played...


The positives..  the atmosphere is fairly unnerving, even with the above mentioned sound issues.  The art style is rather unique and sets it apart from alot of the other FP horror games flooding the market.. The story seems engaging and interesting for the most part.  Provided you care to seek it out from the various scraps of paper which lay around.  The map layout is fairly simplistic to remember (not overly complicated to increase)  the puzzles are simple.

I would have to not recommend this game currently, this may change provided the developer goes back and attempts to fix some of the bugs and glitches I mentioned above, and at the bare minimum includes some type of settings in the game menu.  Subtitles would also be very beneficial, especially for people who are hard of hearing like myself...

reviewText:
Ugh, where to start. One Final Breath is another piece of Unity garbage that's labeled as horror" when in fact it's yet another key finding simulator.

You're an alcoholic father who's divorced because of your alcoholism and you have to go find your daughter. The story is basic and fairly typical in this day and age. You look for keys to unlock doors to get further into being able to find your daughter.

The controls are insanely clunky. Sometimes you have to be really spot on if you want to interact with something. Do you want to strafe while sprinting? Good luck with that. Do you want to sprint at all? Keep hitting shift and hope for the best. By the way
date: your flashlight has a limited battery life; who knew? Certainly not I until it suddenly stopped working
recommended: because there is no battery indicator or mention of this anywhere within the game.\n\nThe emblematic problems that come along with Unity of course plague this game. Consistent FPS? Nah
voteText: even on high end gaming rigs such as mine (specs in profile). The achievements don't even work right. But hey
helpfulPercent: that's what you get when you use an engine that costs $50 to learn and own for life. Unity will be the death of horror games.\n\nRating: 0.5/5.0 - Abysmal
votesHelpful: avoid it like the plague.Belphegore's Hell House Reviews (Group)"

reviewText:
Unity horror games are a dime a dozen. For a lot of them, a dime is also all they‚Äôre worth. One Final Breath is yet another Unity-based horror game. It shows promise, but isn‚Äôt there yet.

As a divorced alcoholic, your ex-wife calls to tell you that your daughter has run away, and because you‚Äôre a divorced alcoholic, you‚Äôre clearly a great father, and decide to go track her down and bring her back home.

You head to St. Mary‚Äôs School, where ‚Äúbelieving in kids, gods gift‚Äù is apparently their poorly worded and grammar lacking motto, and your journey begins. You must find a key to open a door, which will give you another key to open another door, and once in there, you‚Äôll get a keycard, nah just kidding, another key.

Eventually, chapter one ends. And you‚Äôll be scratching your head.

What is annoying is that Episode 0, which I imagine would‚Äôve been a quick prelude to the game, was a cutscene that was about 90 seconds long. Why was this considered an episode? Why couldn‚Äôt the cutscene play at the beginning of episode one, like the vast majority of games?

ProsMusic. For an indie game with what I‚Äôm assuming is a small budget, the music is fairly decent. There‚Äôs not much variation to it, but it isn‚Äôt grating enough to become annoying.

Acting. The acting is surprisingly good. The protagonist definitely sounds like he‚Äôs an alcoholic, and has that gruff, harsh voice of someone who no longer really cares.

ConsGraphics/animation. The graphics are okay. I‚Äôve seen worse. While they get the job done, there‚Äôs a fair amount of artifacting, with objects popping or weird lighting effects that defy the way lights fall. Your character‚Äôs animation is also very stiff, the worst being when you answer your phone, and your arm slowly raises from your side like some sort of battery powered animatronic that‚Äôs in need of a battery change.

Controls. They‚Äôre horrible. Strafing is absolutely atrocious. If you try to combine walking or running while strafing, good luck with that. There are no options to change sensitivity, either.

Psychic protagonist. All of the keys you pick up are what appear to be unmarked metal keys, as shown in your inventory. Yet when you open your inventory, most of the keys have a description of what they‚Äôre for. ‚ÄúB1 Bathroom Key‚Äù or ‚ÄúOffice Key‚Äù. With no markings on them, and we‚Äôre assuming this guy isn‚Äôt part of the staff, because he clearly isn‚Äôt, how does he know which key opens what? Any sort of suspension of disbelief is shattered.

Journals. Throughout the game, there are many journals to read. When you see one, it‚Äôll have the exact same text and be labeled the same, yet when you actually use it, it‚Äôs different text. That text is also very small, and it‚Äôs actually much easier to read what‚Äôs on the paper before you interact with it. Odd design choice and/or lack of‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶attention to detail. It doesn‚Äôt exist. A wheelchair that rolls across the hall in front of you, yet the wheels don‚Äôt actually move. Story notes that are identical. Music that doesn‚Äôt always sound positional (such as the gramophone in the gym). Also, at some point for no reason, my flashlight went out and I couldn't turn it back on. Does the flashlight have a limited battery? If so, that should be portrayed somehow, perhaps with him banging the side of it, hoping it doesn't go out, or just flat out say you have limited time with it. If it's not intended, then it's a very odd bug.

ConclusionIn its current state, the game is a bit below average. It‚Äôs not horrible by any stretch, and there‚Äôs definite promise, but it has a way to go. Controls should be updated to be less clunky, some proofreading wouldn‚Äôt hurt, and most of the design decisions need to be fleshed out.

Try it if it‚Äôs in a bundle, or a giveaway. As there‚Äôs currently only one episode available (as of this review), which can be completed in about 40 minutes or quicker, there‚Äôs not much here for your money (ignore my play time; I finished it before cards unlocked, and it sat idling for a bit to finish). Once all episodes are released, if all episodes are released, it might be worth a second look.

reviewText:
I got this with one of Indiegala's halloween bundles. So if you absolutely have to try it, just get it through those guys.

There's real potential for greatness in this game. On paper, the story isn't half bad and is actually quite intriguing. However, when combined with repetitive gameplay, broken controls and cringe worthy voice acting from our main protagonist, you just have to wonder what exactly happened during its development.

Will I be playing the next episode? Sure, if the developers learn from the criticism and improve upon the gameplay (maybe even get a new voice actor but I might be asking a bit too much there) but I've got a bad feeling that that might not be the case.

This isn't a horror game, it's a boredom simulator. 'Nuff said.

reviewText:
One Final Breath reminds me of another title on steam by the name of Daylight with the atmosphere, and gameplay very similar, with of course One final Breath being broken down into episodic relese similar to how we've grown accustomed to with the Tell Tale series such as Walking Dead / The Wolf Among us etc.

One Final Breath has you taking control of a broken down dad set out to go look for his daughter in St. Mary's Boarding School for Gifted Children.  Graphically One Final Breath might look rough and unpolished but the developers have done a great job at keeping it that way capturing the creepy atmosphere with dark fuzzy and sometimes hard to see spots in the environment where you will need your flashlight to help guide your way.

There is a lot of searching and a bit of puzzle solving but most to move through and progress you need to find keys to unlock doors, quite a little too many keys in my opinion but hopefully in the episodes ahead the developers will try and mix it again and move away from getting player to look for keys and come up with other ways to progress through the level/story.

One Final Breath has the making and potential to be a great creepy horror game, with pretty good voice acting and the controls not too annoying, hopefully with the coming episodes the devs can iron out any bugs and come up with more interesting ways to progress through the story.

reviewText:
One Final Breath is very creepy, you get episode 0 and episode 1, episode 0 is just a little video explaining the story and that you must go looking for your daughter.

Episode 1 you set off to look for your daughter with a flashlight in your hand, there is a lot of exploration with notes giving you info and back story on what happened in the school,  there is a bit of puzzle solving but not too much.

The environment and atmostphere is very well done and if you play it at night with headphones on it will really scare the pants off you.

I'm looking forward to the rest of the episodes being released and Dark Day Interactive	have done a good job so far.

reviewText:
It has potential. Seems like a combination of other horror game themes into one.

Visually too grainy and dark for me.
Could use a flashlight.
Voice acting sounds cliche, needs to be worked on.
Movement control feels lagged behind.

reviewText: This game is a bit rough around the edges, that is for sure. There are small flaws here and there, but it doesn't distract from the charm that the writing and the gameplay give to the player. For the price, it is definitely worth it, and if you just want an entertaining and at times scary, horror-exploration game, this is something to check out.
voteText: 4 of 25 people (16%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I have played through all The Walking Dead seasons by Telltale Games so I thought that I would give this game a try.  I was very surprised to how well this game compares to that! I recommend this game to anyone who has played a game like that or is into any sort of solving mystery games.  This game is very simple to pick up, anyone can jump right in a figure out how to play.  This game is also very life like, for example, when you are going to open a locker, you don't just click and it opens, you actually have to slide your mouse like you are opening it, that is what makes this game unique.\n\nAnother great game from Kickstarter!
voteText: 4 of 27 people (15%) found this review helpful 6 people found this review funny

reviewText:
One Final Breath is a fantastic game that reminds me of Tell-tale‚Äôs style of gaming and storytelling. This makes for a compelling game that keeps you engaged and coming back for more.

The game runs in Unity, which is a great game development architecture which allows for a rich and deep gaming experience.

The graphics of the game are nothing to boast about (in comparison to a triple A title), but that‚Äôs a positive ‚Äì especially as it means that you could run this game on almost any given rig. The frame rate is a constant 60 fps, the controls are simplistic and suitable and the game itself runs well and bug-free in my experience.

The game features an involving storyline, with a rich narrative told through good voice acting and cinematic to match. This is perhaps the strongest element of the game and is carried through well into gameplay. The episodic nature of the game is an interesting choice and keeps you coming back for more content, especially if you like playing narrative games in long bursts (like me)!

I would love for a more in-depth graphics options being built-in to the game‚Äôs menu, and a general expansion of options ‚Äì for example subtitle options, key rebinding and so on. This would make more sense being made accessible in-game rather than through a launcher. It‚Äôs more of a convenience thing.

All-in-all, this is a great game for those who love dynamic storytelling and compelling gameplay. Definitely recommended!

reviewText: Don't know why, but these indie horror games, lags on my computer. It more is like a slowness than studdering, but still, I have a core i7, and a GTX 970m graphics card. There should be no reason for lag. Other than the unbareable lag, it seems like the developers can make this into something good, at least from what I have seen, which isn't much, because again, the unbareable lag. At this time in the game, I would not reccommend purchasing the game.

reviewText:
Well I already played for not even 5 minutes and there are just a few problems I want to say that stand out above the other million problems...
1. The flashlight comes up 5 minutes after you actually press the button to bring up the flashlight
2. The doors make NO sound (like literally when you open a door and you are not moving you will probably never hear anything.
3. The picture of the daughter... Wtf? Were the people who made this game the same stereotypical high schoolers that made anime and it actually looked like ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•?
4. The same goes for the picture of her father, wtf???
5. If you are within a mile radius of an object, YOU WILL HIT IT AND SIT THERE FOR AN HOUR! Matching that with the inCREDIBLY terrible moving system that makes you walk like a turtle if your not walking (literally) foreward.
I literally played this for only about 5-10 minutes and I already regret it.
But dont get me wrong, this game HAS potential but its incredibly hard to forget the millions of problems it has...
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Those who have described this as a key finding simulator aren't wrong. The game consists of five keys and two combination locks. Gameplay is limited to looking for a key (the only object you can pick up, and one of about five types of objects you can interact with - the others being notes, lockers, doors and combination locks); finding the key; opening a door; and looking for another key. There are only two puzzles to solve - one which is solved by opening doors, and one which I guessed and solved in about 30 seconds. That second puzzle may have been the most challenging part of the game.

The game wasn't without atmosphere - most rooms were dark and grungy, except, inexplicably, the bright and clean gymnasium. At tad clich√©d, but workable. The two minor jump scares did nothing for me, but maybe someone else will have more of a response. Notes scattered throughout the game tell the basis of a story.

Controls were a bit flakey - at times it would say to use the mouse or the keyboard to interact, but only the keyboard would work. However, prompts always led you through the possible interactions, which amounted to click, click and drag, or work with your inventory. There was a small bug with items (keys, as there was nothing else to pick up) not always appearing in the player's hand when selected from the inventory, but that was harmless enough.

Overall, a very short introduction to what might prove to be a bigger key finding simulator. Perhaps if other parts of the game a released there will be something there, but this single part isn't worthwhile. It has some atmosphere but almost no gameplay.
voteText: No ratings yet
